instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3435: What is 820-3435? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.SMC_FAN_0_CTL: What is SMC_FAN_0_CTL? SMC_FAN_0_CTL is a line between the SMC and the fan that controls fan speed that is frequently disturbed when someone inexperienced knocks resistors in the area off with their fingernail or screwdriver when unplugging the fan. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message:
I have this liquid damaged machine. Initially the fan spun very fast and was making the 3 beeps Ram sound. I took the machine apart and noticed the underside of the fan was sticky and had liquid damage.
After the board was ultrasonic'd the machine boots fine now but the fan issue remained. In ASD the fan was the only thing to fail. 
I even tried plugging in a fan from a 13" Air but that still did the same thing. 

I put the board under a microscope and noticed that <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> was missing from the board so i put another one on it but still the fans spin on high immediately after the charger is plugged in.
Here are some voltages I get from that area.
<RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> Pin 1 - 3.32v Pin 2 - quickly pulses around 0.85v but then stays at 0.05v
<RESISTOR>R6065</RESISTOR> Pin 1&2 - 1.62v
<RESISTOR>R6060</RESISTOR> Pin 1 - 3.32v Pin 2 - 1.61v

J6000
Pin 1 - 5.1v
Pin 2 - 1.62v
Pin 3 - 4.63v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message: Is fan RPM correctly displayed in ASD profile? <RESISTOR>R6065</RESISTOR> checked? Diode mode on the tach line? crap under SMC possible too.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message:
Diode mode of TACH (Pin 2 of J6000) is 0.635v

I have the voltage measurements of <RESISTOR>R6065</RESISTOR> above and the resistance of it shows 43.5kohms

I attached an image of the RPM profile. I believe the reading was 6131 RPM.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message: So the tach signal is working fine. So your problem must be around <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> as the setpoint is 1200. Check <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> and check traces to/from <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> and possibly another <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message:
I checked the traces that go from <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> and all of them were fine. I put another <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> on the board but still the same issue remains.
I measured <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> on pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> and it still just pulses very quickly at around 0.85v then just stays at 0.05v. Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> is a steady 3.32v.

Could it be an issue with the fan or the fan connector?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message: I had assumed you tried another fan of course. It could be crap under the SMC too.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message: I tried with a fan from a 13" Macbook and it does the same thing. Are those fans compatible or do I need to get a fan for an 11" machine?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message: They are the same. Voltage on <SIGNAL>FAN_RT_PWM</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> ?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message:
Okay I put flux on the SMC and heated it up but not to the point of it being reflowed.  Also, when I looked around the corroded JTAG connector that I previosly removed I noticed that <RESISTOR>R6115</RESISTOR> was missing from the board so I may have knocked that off when I initially removed the JTAG. I put <RESISTOR>R6115</RESISTOR> back on the board but the fan issue still remains.

Here are some measurements I got now.
<SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> on Pin 2 of <RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> is a steady 3.41v. Before it would only pulse initially at 0.85v and then stay at 0.05v.

<SIGNAL>FAN_RT_PWM</SIGNAL> is a steady 4.65v
Pins 1/2 of <RESISTOR>R6065</RESISTOR> is still around 1.65v

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message:
Run ASD again and check fan speed and set point again. If set point is at 1200RPM and <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> is at 3.41V then something is pulling up that line. So either something with <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> or the SMC.
Check resistance between <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> and PP3V42.

I assume there are no sensor errors in ASD!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message:
I ran ASD and there were no errors except on the fan section. The setpoint said 1200rpm and the speed was 6059rpm. I checked <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> and it was again showing 0.05v. What voltage should it be at?

Resistance between <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is around 218 kohms

I just measured <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> a couple more times and its back to doing the pulsing 0.85v and then stays at a steady 0.05v.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> is correct at pretty much 0V. SMC is seeing 6000RPM so it will try and bring that down. Still there is a <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR> problem because it's output is stuck at 4.65V. Compare voltages to a known good board and inspect the traces to <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR>.

Edit:

Actually that is wrong it is an N-channel so if gate is low it will be fully on. Check diode mode on <SIGNAL>SMC_FAN_0_CTL</SIGNAL> and check if the pull up resistor <RESISTOR>R6061</RESISTOR> is good and traces.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3435</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spinning on high
threads.message:
Thanks duke the issue was in fact <TRANSISTOR>Q6060</TRANSISTOR>. I removed it and noticed one of the pads on the chip were gone and the same thing happened with 2 more chips that I pulled from donors. I found a clean one and now the fan is working as it should.

Thanks you can mark this as solved.
